content.raw:
Does anybody have any idea why inserting the <sensor> element in a .sdf file works while inserting it into a .gazebo file or into a .urdf (for later conversion to .sdf) does not?
[(here is the link to my question in gazebo answers.. thought could get more relevant help here)](http://answers.gazebosim.org/question/4708/sensor-elements-in-urdf-disappearing-when/)
content.html: Does anybody have any idea why inserting the <sensor> element in a .sdf file works while inserting it into a .gazebo file or into a .urdf (for later conversion to .sdf) does not? (here is the link to my question in gazebo answers.. thought could get more relevant help here)

update.description:
This pull-request is very low priority. Keep in mind that nightly builds are not targeted from default, so this should not affect the VRC.

Two new sensors have been added: Sonar, and Force Torque.

The sonar sensor currently uses a cone mesh for detecting range values. The force-torque sensor is a light wrapper around joint feedback.

Both sensors can be visualized in the GUI.

Example worlds: `worlds/sonar_demo.world` and `worlds/force_torque_demo.world`

Resolves Issue #379
update.title: Sonar and Force Torque sensors

content.raw:
I think the issue is that this function `Joint::FillMsg` can get called before sensors have had a chance to load. For example, `World::LoadModel` calls `Model::FillMsg`, which calls `Joint::FillMsg`.

I'll add a gzlog message.
content.html:
I think the issue is that this function Joint::FillMsg can get called before sensors have had a chance to load. For example, World::LoadModel calls Model::FillMsg, which calls Joint::FillMsg.

I'll add a gzlog message.

content.raw: It looks like he is changing the GZ_ASSERT to look at `this->sdf` rather than `_sdf`, since the former is the one that is actually dereferenced. I think it's an ok change.
content.html: It looks like he is changing the GZ_ASSERT to look at this->sdf rather than _sdf, since the former is the one that is actually dereferenced. I think it's an ok change.

content.raw: This branch has been merged with default and installs to gazebo_1.9 now, but I've just reproduced it. Another symptom is that the client appears unable to add new visuals once it gets into this state. If I insert a new model, it's visuals will not be created. I can see the contacts from models, and I can see everything if I open a new gzclient.
content.html: This branch has been merged with default and installs to gazebo_1.9 now, but I've just reproduced it. Another symptom is that the client appears unable to add new visuals once it gets into this state. If I insert a new model, it's visuals will not be created. I can see the contacts from models, and I can see everything if I open a new gzclient.

content.raw: Is a null value a valid option as a return of the get_sensor function using an input from the sensors list? If it could hide a bug, I would prefer not to jump over it but at least warn (gzerror) or better to fail (GZ_ASSERT).
content.html: Is a null value a valid option as a return of the get_sensor function using an input from the sensors list? If it could hide a bug, I would prefer not to jump over it but at least warn (gzerror) or better to fail (GZ_ASSERT).

content.raw: I'm not sure that change here is doing something sane, except to try to resist a input of NULL under certain conditions. Is this desired? If null is not an option, I would prefer to fail fast
content.html: I'm not sure that change here is doing something sane, except to try to resist a input of NULL under certain conditions. Is this desired? If null is not an option, I would prefer to fail fast

I was testing the sonar sensor with multiple objects, and it doesn't always report the distance of the closest object. The following diff improves the behavior I think.

diff -r 8fe95af2eafd gazebo/sensors/SonarSensor.cc
--- a/gazebo/sensors/SonarSensor.cc Wed Jun 26 07:57:57 2013 -0700
+++ b/gazebo/sensors/SonarSensor.cc Fri Jul 05 16:43:41 2013 -0700
@@ -243,6 +243,8 @@
   math::Pose referencePose = this->pose + this->parentEntity->GetWorldPose();
   math::Vector3 pos;

+  this->sonarMsg.mutable_sonar()->set_range(-1);
+
   // Iterate over all the contact messages
   for (ContactMsgs_L::iterator iter = this->incomingContacts.begin();
       iter != this->incomingContacts.end(); ++iter)
@@ -254,8 +256,6 @@
       // std::cout << "Collision1[" << (*iter)->contact(i).collision1() << "]"
       //  << "C2[" << (*iter)->contact(i).collision2() << "]\n";

-      this->sonarMsg.mutable_sonar()->set_range(-1);
-
       for (int j = 0; j < (*iter)->contact(i).position_size(); ++j)
       {
         pos = msgs::Convert((*iter)->contact(i).position(j));

Also, it doesn't always report the correct distance to the surface of a sphere, since the ODE sphere / mesh contact points are generated inside of the sphere.

content.raw:
Perhaps this could be made more generic by modifying the `GZ_REGISTER_STATIC_SENSOR` macro to specify what is a valid parent type. For example:
~~~
GZ_REGISTER_STATIC_SENSOR("sonar", SonarSensor)
~~~
would become
~~~
GZ_REGISTER_STATIC_SENSOR("sonar", SonarSensor, "link")
~~~
and
~~~
GZ_REGISTER_STATIC_SENSOR("force_torque", ForceTorqueSensor)
~~~
would become
~~~
GZ_REGISTER_STATIC_SENSOR("force_torque", ForceTorqueSensor, "joint")
~~~
content.html:
Perhaps this could be made more generic by modifying the GZ_REGISTER_STATIC_SENSOR macro to specify what is a valid parent type. For example:

GZ_REGISTER_STATIC_SENSOR("sonar", SonarSensor)

would become

GZ_REGISTER_STATIC_SENSOR("sonar", SonarSensor, "link")

and

GZ_REGISTER_STATIC_SENSOR("force_torque", ForceTorqueSensor)

would become

GZ_REGISTER_STATIC_SENSOR("force_torque", ForceTorqueSensor, "joint")

content.raw: We could update this list with the new sensor types: force_torque, sonar, and gpu_ray.
content.html: We could update this list with the new sensor types: force_torque, sonar, and gpu_ray.

content.raw: You could replace `this->sdf->GetValueDouble("length")` with `_length`.
content.html: You could replace this->sdf->GetValueDouble("length") with _length.

content.raw: You could replace `this->sdf->GetValueDouble("radius")` with `_radius`.
content.html: You could replace this->sdf->GetValueDouble("radius") with _radius.

content.raw: I've only been able to reproduce this when I have both gazebo_1.9 and gazebo_1.8 installed. This branch currently installs into gazebo_1.8, but the default setup.sh will source gazebo_1.9.

content.raw:
Very occasionally I see a mismatch between server and gui model positions when dragging the model from one place to another, see  [screenshot](https://www.dropbox.com/s/a8gqohbb1evy3n1/gui_drag_mismatch.png). 

In the screenshot, the wireframe moves as I drag the model with the mouse but the solid model remains in the same position. Not sure if it's something introduced in this branch or the issue is already present in default. Need to test more.
content.html:
Very occasionally I see a mismatch between server and gui model positions when dragging the model from one place to another, see screenshot.

In the screenshot, the wireframe moves as I drag the model with the mouse but the solid model remains in the same position. Not sure if it's something introduced in this branch or the issue is already present in default. Need to test more.
